content.title: May-Thurner Syndrome (Iliac Vein Compression)
content.summary: Anatomical variant where the left common iliac vein is compressed between the overlying right common iliac artery and the lumbar spine, predisposing to left lower extremity DVT and chronic venous symptoms.

definitions.definition: Compression of the left common iliac vein by the right common iliac artery against the lumbar vertebrae, leading to venous outflow obstruction and increased DVT risk.
Intraluminal fibrous band or web that develops in the compressed iliac vein due to chronic pulsatile arterial trauma, causing additional stenosis.

key_concepts.explanation: Classic MTS: left CIV compressed by right CIA. Variants include: right-sided MTS (right CIV compression), bilateral compression, and external iliac compression. Anatomic compression is present in 20-30% of the population but only a minority become symptomatic.

Acute: iliofemoral DVT, often in young otherwise healthy patients (especially women). Chronic: leg swelling, venous claudication, varicosities, skin changes (CVI). Some present with both acute thrombus and underlying chronic stenosis.

IVUS is the gold standard for diagnosis and shows >50% stenosis and/or venous spur. CT venography and MR venography show compression but may underestimate severity. Conventional venography with pressure measurements can demonstrate obstruction.

Iliac vein stenting is the primary treatment for symptomatic MTS. Use dedicated venous stents (larger diameter, crush-resistant). Stenting for acute DVT is combined with catheter-directed thrombolysis. Primary patency rates exceed 90% at 1-2 years.

evidence.citation: Raju et al., Iliac Vein Stenting Series, 2006
evidence.finding: Iliac vein stenting provides durable relief with 95% primary patency at 2 years and significant symptom improvement
Pharmacomechanical CDT did not reduce post-thrombotic syndrome overall but may benefit those with iliofemoral DVT (subgroup analysis)

clinical_pearls: MTS should be suspected in any patient with left-sided iliofemoral DVT, especially young women
After treating acute DVT, always evaluate for underlying MTS - recurrence rate is high without stenting
IVUS reveals abnormalities missed by cross-sectional imaging in 30-40% of cases
Anticoagulation alone is insufficient; stenting addresses the anatomic cause
Pregnancy and oral contraceptives increase thrombosis risk in MTS patients
learning_objectives: Describe the anatomical basis of May-Thurner syndrome
Compare diagnostic modalities for MTS evaluation
State indications for iliac vein stenting in MTS
Outline post-stent anticoagulation and surveillance protocols

cross_domain_references.context: MTS is an anatomic cause of venous thrombosis
